title: Definite Article
description: The definite article ה attaches to the beginning of a noun to indicate it is a definite (rather than indefinite) noun.

title: Construct State
description: When a noun is modified by another noun, the first noun is in the construct state, indicated by changes to the noun's form.

title: Inseparable Prepositions
description: The prepositions ב, כ, and ל attach directly to the beginning of a noun, without a separate word.

title: Adjectives
description: Adjectives agree with the noun they modify in gender and number, and typically follow the noun they modify.

title: Pronouns
description: Personal pronouns indicate the speaker, listener, or topic.  Demonstrative pronouns point out a noun.

title: Qal Verb Paradigm
description: The Qal is the basic, unmodified verb stem.  Qal verbs conjugate for person, number, and gender.

title: Infinitive Construct
description: The infinitive construct is a non-finite verb form used to express an action without reference to time, person, or number.

title: Participles
description: Participles are verbal adjectives that describe an ongoing action.  They can function as nouns, adjectives, or verbs.

title: Absolute and Construct State Nouns
description: Nouns can appear in either the absolute state (independent) or the construct state (when modifying another noun).

title: Prepositions
description: Prepositions indicate the relationship between a noun and other parts of the sentence, such as location, time, or manner.

title: Cardinal Numbers
description: Cardinal numbers indicate quantity, and can modify nouns to specify how many.
examples: אִישׁ אֶחָד, שְׁנֵי אֲנָשִׁים, שְׁלֹשָׁה נְעָרִים

title: Ordinal Numbers
description: Ordinal numbers indicate position in a sequence, and modify nouns to specify which one.
examples: הַיּוֹם הָרִאשׁוֹן, הַשָּׁבוּעַ הַשֵּׁנִי, הַחֹדֶשׁ הַשְּׁלִישִׁי

title: Interrogative Pronouns
description: Interrogative pronouns ask a question, such as who, what, where, when, why, or how.

title: Copulative Sentences
description: Copulative sentences use the verb
to equate the subject and predicate.

title: Possessive Pronouns
description: Possessive pronouns indicate ownership or belonging, and agree with the possessed noun in gender and number.

title: Demonstrative Pronouns
description: Demonstrative pronouns point out a particular noun, and agree with it in gender and number.
examples: זֶה הַסֵּפֶר, זֹאת הָאֳנִיָּה, אֵלֶּה הָאֲנָשִׁים

title: Independent Personal Pronouns
description: Independent personal pronouns can function as the subject of a sentence, or as the object of a preposition.

title: Suffixed Personal Pronouns
description: Suffixed personal pronouns attach directly to the end of a noun or preposition to indicate possession or object.

title: Imperative Mood
description: The imperative mood expresses a command or request, and only has second-person forms.

title: Cohortative Mood
description: The cohortative mood expresses a wish or exhortation, and typically appears with the first-person singular or plural.

title: Jussive Mood
description: The jussive mood expresses a wish or command, and typically appears with the third-person singular or plural.

title: Consecutive Waw
description: The consecutive waw connects a verb to the previous clause, indicating a consecutive or narrative sequence of events.

title: Dative of Advantage
description: The dative of advantage indicates the person or thing for whose benefit or advantage an action is performed.

title: Locative Heh
description: The locative heh indicates a specific location or direction, often with nouns referring to cities or countries.

title: Definite Direct Object
description: The definite direct object marker אֶת indicates that the noun it precedes is the definite direct object of the verb.

title: Waw Conversive
description: The waw conversive changes the tense of a verb, typically from past to future or vice versa.

title: Infinitive Absolute
description: The infinitive absolute is a non-finite verb form used to emphasize the verbal idea, often in conjunction with a finite verb.

title: Niphal Verb Stem
description: The Niphal stem is a passive or reflexive verb form, indicating the subject undergoes the action of the verb.

title: Piel Verb Stem
description: The Piel stem is an intensive or causative verb form, indicating the subject causes the action of the verb.

title: Hiphil Verb Stem
description: The Hiphil stem is a causative verb form, indicating the subject causes the action of the verb.

title: Hophal Verb Stem
description: The Hophal stem is a passive causative verb form, indicating the subject undergoes a caused action.

title: Hitpael Verb Stem
description: The Hitpael stem is a reflexive or reciprocal verb form, indicating the subject acts upon itself or each other.

title: Weak Verbs: Pe-Nun
description: Pe-Nun verbs have a נ as the first root letter, which causes certain changes in the verb paradigm.

title: Weak Verbs: Lamed-He
description: Lamed-He verbs have a ה as the third root letter, which causes certain changes in the verb paradigm.

title: Weak Verbs: Ayin-Vav/Yod
description: Ayin-Vav/Yod verbs have a ו or י as the second root letter, which causes certain changes in the verb paradigm.

title: Construct State Nouns with Suffixes
description: Nouns in the construct state can take pronominal suffixes to indicate possession.

title: Relative Clause
description: A relative clause modifies a noun by providing additional information about it, beginning with the relative pronoun אֲשֶׁר.

title: Genitive Construct
description: The genitive construct links two nouns, where the first noun is possessed by the second.

title: Dative Infinitive
description: The dative infinitive expresses purpose or result, and is often introduced by the preposition לְ.

title: Adverbial Infinitive
description: The adverbial infinitive expresses manner, means, or circumstance, often without a preposition.

title: Temporal Clauses
description: Temporal clauses indicate when an action takes place, and are often introduced by conjunctions like כַּאֲשֶׁר, כְּשֶׁ, or בְּטֶרֶם.

title: Conditional Clauses
description: Conditional clauses indicate an action that is contingent on another condition, and are often introduced by אִם.

title: Purpose Clauses
description: Purpose clauses indicate the reason or purpose for an action, and are often introduced by לְמַעַן or לְמַען.

title: Result Clauses
description: Result clauses indicate the result or consequence of an action, and are often introduced by עַד כִּי or עַד אֲשֶׁר.
examples: הִכָּה אֶת הָאֹיֵב עַד כִּי נָפַל
הִרְבָּה לִשְׁמֹר עַד אֲשֶׁר נִשְׁמְרוּ הַמִּצְווֹת
הֶעֱמִיק לִלְמֹד עַד אֲשֶׁר הָיָה חָכָם

title: Explanatory Clauses
description: Explanatory clauses provide additional information or explanation about a preceding statement, often introduced by כִּי.
examples: שָׁמַר הָאִישׁ אֶת הַמִּצְווֹת, כִּי יָרֵא אֱלֹהִים הָיָה

title: Comparative Clauses
description: Comparative clauses compare two things, often using the comparative particle כְּ.

title: Concessive Clauses
description: Concessive clauses indicate something is true despite a contradictory condition, often using אַף כִּי or אַף עַל פִּי.
examples: אַף כִּי רָעֵב הָיָה, לֹא אָכַל
אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁיָּגֵעַ, לֹא שָׁב

title: Indirect Discourse
description: Indirect discourse reports speech or thought indirectly, without using quotation marks.

title: Hendiadys
description: Hendiadys is a rhetorical figure where two words connected by
express a single complex idea.

title: Inclusio
description: Inclusio is a literary device where the beginning and end of a passage or section share the same or similar words.

title: Merismus
description: Merismus is a figure of speech that uses two contrasting parts to refer to a whole.

title: Emphatic Infinitive
description: The emphatic infinitive uses the infinitive absolute in addition to a finite verb to emphasize the verbal idea.

title: Elative Adjectives
description: Elative adjectives express the idea of
or
, and are formed with certain patterns.

title: Nisbe Adjectives
description: Nisbe adjectives are relational adjectives that indicate belonging or relationship.

title: Diachronic Changes
description: Over time, certain sound changes occurred in biblical Hebrew, such as the shift from /ā/ to /ō/.

title: Poetic Devices
description: Biblical Hebrew poetry makes use of various literary devices like parallelism, chiasm, and acrostics.

title: Kinship Terms
description: Biblical Hebrew has a rich set of kinship terms to describe family and social relationships.

title: Gentilics
description: Gentilics are adjectives that indicate the ethnic or geographic origin of a person or thing.

title: Reduplication
description: Reduplication is the repetition of a root or stem to express intensity, frequency, or distributivity.

title: Vocatives
description: Vocatives are nouns or noun phrases used to directly address someone or something.

title: Enclitic Mem
description: The enclitic mem is a demonstrative or emphatic particle that attaches to the end of a word.

title: Heterophones
description: Heterophones are words that are spelled the same but have different pronunciations and meanings.

title: Hendiadys in Poetry
description: Hendiadys is especially common in biblical poetry, where it adds rhythm and parallelism.

title: Ellipsis
description: Ellipsis is the omission of one or more words that are implied by the context.
examples: וַיַּעַל וַיֵּרֶד (he went up and he went down)
הַגֵּר וְהַתּוֹשָׁב (the sojourner and the resident)

title: Zeugma
description: Zeugma is a rhetorical figure where a single word governs two or more other words.
examples: אָדָם וּבְהֵמָה תּוֹשִׁיעַ יְהוָה (man and beast, Yahweh will save)
אָב לִיתוֹמִים וְדַיַּן אַלְמָנוֹת (a father to the fatherless and a judge for widows)
וְאֶת יְרוּשָׁלַיִם וְאֶת הַר צִיּוֹן אָהַבְתִּי (and Jerusalem and Mount Zion I have loved)

title: Asyndeton
description: Asyndeton is the omission of conjunctions between words, phrases, or clauses.
examples: לָלֶכֶת בַּדֶּרֶךְ הַטּוֹבָה הַיְשָׁרָה (to walk in the good, upright way)
הֶחֱזִיק בְּיָדוֹ הֶעֱמִיד עַל כִּסְאוֹ (he took him by the hand, he established him on his throne)
צֵא תָּשׁוּב נָא שׁוּב (go, return now, return)

title: Polysyndeton
description: Polysyndeton is the repetition of conjunctions between words, phrases, or clauses.
examples: וּבֵרַכְתִּיךָ וְהִרְבֵּיתִי אֶת זַרְעֲךָ (and I will bless you and I will multiply your offspring)
וְאֶת הַיּוֹם וְאֶת הַלַּיְלָה (both the day and the night)
וְשָׁמַרְתָּ וְעָשִׂיתָ וְיָרֵאתָ (and you shall keep and you shall do and you shall fear)

title: Chiasm
description: Chiasm is a literary device where the order of words in the first half of a passage is reversed in the second half.
examples: גָּדוֹל יְהוָה וּמְהֻלָּל מְאֹד, וְלִגְדֻלָּתוֹ אֵין חֵקֶר (Great is Yahweh and greatly to be praised, and to his greatness there is no searching)
לֹא יָמוּשׁ סֵפֶר הַתּוֹרָה הַזֶּה מִפִּיךָ, וְהָגִיתָ בוֹ יוֹמָם וָלָיְלָה (This book of the law shall not depart from your mouth, but you shall meditate on it day and night)
אָדָם לְעָמָל יִוָּלֵד, וּבְנֵי רֶשֶׁף יַגְבִּיהוּ עוּף (Man is born to trouble, and the sons of the flame lift up to fly)

title: Merismus in Poetry
description: Merismus is especially common in biblical poetry, where it adds conciseness and poetic parallelism.
examples: אֵין כָּמוֹךָ בָאֱלֹהִים, אֲדֹנָי (There is none like you among the gods, O Lord)
מִשָּׁמַיִם הִשְׁקִיפָה, וּרְאֵה מְעוֹן קָדְשֶׁךָ (Look down from heaven and see, from your holy habitation)
הַמַּרְבֶּה לֹא הִרְבָּה, וְהַמַּמְעִיט לֹא הִמְעִיט (He who gathered much had nothing left over, and he who gathered little had no lack)

title: Hendiadys in Wisdom Literature
description: Hendiadys is frequently used in biblical wisdom literature to express complex ideas concisely.

title: Rhetorical Questions
description: Rhetorical questions are questions asked not for information, but to make a point.
examples: הֲלֹא אֱלֹהִים יְבַקֵּשׁ אֶת זֹאת? (Will not God seek this out?)
מִי כָמֹכָה בָּאֵלִם יְהוָה? (Who is like you among the gods, O Yahweh?)
הֲיֵשׁ קָצֶה לְחָכְמָתוֹ? (Is there an end to his understanding?)

title: Oath Formulas
description: Oath formulas invoke a divine being to bear witness to a solemn promise or declaration.
examples: נִשְׁבַּעְתִּי בִי (I have sworn by myself)

title: Particle אֵת
description: The particle אֵת is used to mark the definite direct object, similar to the English
examples: בָּרָא אֱלֹהִים אֵת הַשָּׁמַיִם וְאֵת הָאָרֶץ

title: Particle הִנֵּה
description: The particle הִנֵּה is used to draw attention to something, similar to the English

title: Particle כִּי
description: The particle כִּי has a range of uses, including marking causal, temporal, or conditional clauses.
examples: אַשְׁרֵי הָאִישׁ כִּי יָרֵא אֶת יְהוָה

title: Particle אִם
description: The particle אִם is used to introduce conditional clauses, similar to the English

title: Particle לוּ
description: The particle לוּ expresses a wish or hypothetical situation, similar to the English

title: Particle הֲ
description: The particle הֲ is used to mark a yes/no question, similar to the English

title: Particle הֲלֹא
description: The particle הֲלֹא is used to introduce a rhetorical question expecting a positive answer.

title: Particle גַּם
description: The particle גַּם is used to add emphasis or indicate inclusion, similar to the English
or

title: Particle רַק
description: The particle רַק is used to indicate limitation or restriction, similar to the English

title: Particle אוּלַי
description: The particle אוּלַי expresses uncertainty or possibility, similar to the English

title: Particle אַךְ
description: The particle אַךְ is used to indicate contrast or restriction, similar to the English
or

title: Particle אוֹ
description: The particle אוֹ is used to introduce alternative options or possibilities.
